title: New York calls PepsiCo's plastic pollution a 'public nuisance' in first-of-its-kind lawsuit - Grist
summary: PepsiCo has been sued by the New York Attorney General for creating plastic pollution in the Buffalo River watershed. The lawsuit alleges that PepsiCo is responsible for more than 17 percent of the plastic waste found in the river and its tributaries. The lawsuit seeks to require PepsiCo to reduce the amount of plastic packaging entering the river and remediate pollution that has already occurred.

title: Dow funds seven new new business and sustainability projects to drive social impact - Dow Corporate
summary: Dow's 2023 Business Impact Fund supports seven projects that focus on circularity, waste transformation, and social impact initiatives in partnership with NGOs, non-profits, and customers.  Projects include improving waste management and recycling transparency, expanding a circular economy for polyurethanes, advancing menstrual hygiene awareness and access, establishing a recycling system for used soap bars, converting flexible plastic packaging into circular feedstock, introducing recyclable grain bags for farmers, and assessing recycling landscape to improve recycling rates. Dow has invested nearly $12 million in 58 projects in 22 countries since launching the Impact Fund in 2016.
green_innovation: TRUE, the described projects contribute to environmental sustainability goals, such as reducing or replacing harmful substances, reducing resource consumption by developing a circular economy, and nature and wildlife conservation.
business_innovation: TRUE, the described projects involve new or improved products or business processes that differ significantly from the firm's previous products or business processes.
green_product: TRUE, several of the projects involve the development or use of green products, such as recyclable grain bags.
green_process: TRUE, several of the projects involve the development or use of green processes, such as the use of blockchain technology to improve the impact and transparency of waste management and recycling systems, and the use of low-temperature heat induction-based pyrolysis technology to convert low-value used flexible plastic packaging into circular feedstock.

title: What should be done with the millions of used tyres? - Polytechnique Insights
summary: The article discusses the collection and recycling of used tires in France. Over 532,000 tonnes of tires were collected in 2021, and 35.8% of those were recycled. The preferred method of recovery under the Environment Code is material recovery, but most end-of-life tires are recovered in the form of energy. However, tougher regulations and the development of new technologies, such as pyrolysis, are pushing the industry to increase the proportion of end-of-life tires recycled.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article mentions that pyrolysis is a green innovation that can be used to recycle used tires. Pyrolysis is a process that heats the tire to a very high temperature in the absence of oxygen, and it can recover a number of products, including carbon black, pyrolysis oil, steel-metal reinforcements, gas, and textiles.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article mentions that pyrolysis is a new technology that can be used to recycle used tires. This is a business innovation because it is a new way to recover materials from used tires.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not discuss any specific green products.
green_process: TRUE - The article mentions that pyrolysis is a green process because it can be used to recover materials from used tires and reduce waste.

greenwashing: FALSE - The article describes a real green innovation and process (pyrolysis) that can be used to recycle used tires.

title: Defra considering provision to offset closed-loop systems in packaging regs - Resource.co
summary: The UK government is considering implementing a provision to support closed-loop recycling systems in response to feedback received during consultation on the draft Producer Responsibility Obligations (Packaging and Packaging Waste) Regulations. The consultation found that stakeholders were concerned that the incoming EPR regulations would disincentivize investments into closed-loop recycling systems. Companies have voiced fears that despite investing in a closed-loop system, they will be taxed as if their products are entering the waste system.

title: Industry welcomes Environment Ministers' packaging plan - PKN Packaging News
summary: Australia's Environment Ministers have announced plans to implement a collaborative, national approach to packaging regulation, along with a focus on design standards and traceability. The new regulations will mandate how packaging is designed, set minimum recycled content requirements, and prohibit harmful chemicals from being used. This is expected to drive investment, minimize waste, and support circular economy outcomes.

title: Malakoff Geared To Support Malaysia's Environmental Goals - BusinessToday
summary: Malakoff Corporation Berhad (Malakoff) provides solid waste management and public cleansing, infrastructure cleansing and waste solutions, integrated facility management, recycling, marine and hazardous waste solutions, water desalination and waste-to-energy in Malaysia. Malakoff is exploring the Waste-to-Energy (WTE) sector, as part of its sustainable practices. With its vast experience in waste management and environmental solutions, the company is looking to provide waste solutions to more businesses including commercial organisations and ports.
